canDoStatements: I can understand and use basic family vocabulary
I can introduce my family members
I can ask and answer simple questions about family
I can describe basic family relationships
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Possessive adjectives (my, your, his, her, their)

vocabulary.usageNotes: Formal: mother, Informal: mom/mum

vocabulary.example: My father works in an office.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Formal: father, Informal: dad/daddy

vocabulary.example: I have one sister and two brothers.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be older or younger sister

vocabulary.example: My brother is taller than me.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be older or younger brother

vocabulary.example: She has a daughter and a son.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe a female child of any age

vocabulary.example: Their son is five years old.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe a male child of any age
Formal: grandmother, Informal: grandma/granny
Formal: grandfather, Informal: grandpa/granddad

vocabulary.example: My aunt lives in New York.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can also refer to your uncle's wife

vocabulary.example: My uncle drives a red car.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can also refer to your aunt's husband

vocabulary.definition: The child of your aunt or uncle
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be male or female cousin
Used for married men
Used for married women
Usually refers to children under 2 years old

vocabulary.definition: A group of people related by blood or marriage
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can refer to immediate or extended family
Plural form of parent
Plural form of child

vocabulary.example: My grandparents live in the country.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Plural form referring to both grandmother and grandfather
Gender-neutral term for brothers and sisters

vocabulary.definition: People related by blood or marriage
vocabulary.example: I have many relatives in Italy.
vocabulary.usageNotes: General term for extended family members

vocabulary.definition: The wife of your father (not your biological mother)
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used when parents are divorced or separated

vocabulary.definition: The husband of your mother (not your biological father)
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used when parents are divorced or separated

vocabulary.definition: One of two children born at the same time
vocabulary.example: My twin sister looks like me.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be twin brother or twin sister

vocabulary.definition: The daughter of your brother or sister
vocabulary.usageNotes: Female child of your sibling

vocabulary.definition: The son of your brother or sister
vocabulary.usageNotes: Male child of your sibling

exercises.title: Match Family Members
exercises.description: Match the family member with their definition

exercises.title: Complete the Sentences
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct family vocabulary

items.sentence: I have one ___ and two brothers.

exercises.title: Family Conversation
exercises.description: Practice asking and answering questions about family

scenarios.question: How many people are in your family?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: There are four people in my family: my mother, my father, my sister, and me.

scenarios.question: Do you have any brothers or sisters?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: Yes, I have one sister and one brother.

possessiveAdjectives.title: Possessive Adjectives
possessiveAdjectives.description: Learn to use my, your, his, her, their with family members
rules: Use 'my' for things that belong to you
Use 'your' for things that belong to the person you're talking to
Use 'his' for things that belong to a male
Use 'her' for things that belong to a female
Use 'their' for things that belong to more than one person
